back.definition: Conecta networks entre offices/data centers. IPsec tunnel. Routers/firewalls terminan tunnel. Transparent para users.
back.example: HQ en NY, branch en LA. Site-to-site VPN = single network lógico. IPsec with ESP (encryption) + AH (authentication).

back.definition: Usuarios remotos conectan a corporate network. Client software. SSL/TLS based (easier) o IPsec (más secure).
back.example: OpenVPN, Cisco AnyConnect, WireGuard. COVID-19: Remote work exploded VPN usage. Bandwidth bottleneck.

back.definition: Alternative a VPN. No 'trusted network'. Identity-based access. Micro-segmentation. Never trust, verify always.
back.example: Cloudflare Access, Zscaler Private Access. User autentica, accede SOLO recursos específicos. No full network access como VPN tradicional.

unlock_content.title: No Solo Passwords
points: MFA: TOTP, push notification, hardware token
Disable split-tunneling (force all traffic through VPN)
Monitor for concurrent sessions (same user, different locations)
unlock_content.bonus_fact: VPN sin MFA = low-hanging fruit para attackers. Credential stuffing hits VPNs hard.

unlock_content.title: Protocol Selection
points: WireGuard: Modern, fast, secure. 4K lines code vs OpenVPN 70K
unlock_content.bonus_fact: WireGuard: Auditable, included in Linux kernel. OpenVPN works pero heavy.

options.feedback: Incorrecto. Son approaches diferentes para remote access.

options.text: VPN da acceso a network completo; ZTNA da acceso granular a recursos específicos
options.feedback: CORRECTO! VPN tradicional: User conecta, tiene acceso a entire corporate network (flat network). ZTNA: Identity-based, user accede SOLO a apps/recursos específicos authorized. Zero Trust = never trust network location, always verify identity + context.
Incorrecto. ZTNA SÍ usa encryption (TLS). Diferencia no es encryption sino modelo de trust y granularidad de access.
